I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation for a proposed loan 
for CNY130 million for the Microfinance Wholesale Lending Facility in the People’s Republic of 
China (PRC). The facility will be offered to participating partner banks to develop the wholesale 
lending market for microcredit companies (MCCs). The facility will promote access to credit for 
households  and  micro  and  small  enterprises  (MSEs),  particularly  those  in  rural  areas. 1  The 
investment will be funded from ADB’s ordinary capital resources.2
 

II. 

BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 

A. 

Sector Background 

The  outstanding  economic  performance  of  the  PRC3  is  accompanied  by  a  number  of 
2. 
serious imbalances—between coastal and inland regions, between urban and rural areas, and 
between  high  demand  for  natural  resources  and  the  need  for  energy  efficiency  and 
environmental  conservation.  Balanced  and  inclusive  growth  is  one  of  the  main  themes  in  the 
government’s  12th  Five-Year  Plan  (2011–2015).4  Development  of  inclusive  finance  has  been 
seen  by  the  government  and  by  ADB  as  one  of  the  key  policy  measures  to  achieve  inclusive 
growth. 5  The  PRC  banking  system  has  played  a  dominant  role  in  the  financial  market  by 
mobilizing  a  large  pool  of  deposits  and  providing  an  estimated  95%  of  corporate  financing. 
However, many MSEs are facing serious difficulties in accessing credit.6
 

3. 
Microfinance  in  the  PRC  is  at  an  early  stage  of  development.  There  were  no 
commercially sustainable microfinance institutions (MFIs) in 2003.  In 2004, ADB partnered with 
the People’s Bank of China (PBC), the central bank, to develop MCCs as private-sector-owned 
and commercial MFIs through pilots in the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region and in Guizhou 
7 From seven MCCs in five provinces in 2005 this segment of the microfinance market 
Province.
has grown  rapidly  to more than 3,600  MCCs  in  all  provinces  and municipalities  by  end-2011.8
 
MCCs  predominantly  focus  on  micro  lending,  targeting  local  farming  households,  sole 
proprietors, and entrepreneurs. 

MCCs are the first group of private-sector-owned financial institutions in the PRC. They 
4. 
face many regulatory constraints—on the limited geographic area of operation, business scope, 

                                                
1  The new classification of micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises in the PRC was made effective on 18 June 
2011  to  be  more  comparable  to  international  systems.  Generally,  classifications  are  based  on  the  amount  of 
revenue,  number  of  employees,  or  size  of  assets  for  different  sectors.  In  the  industry  sector,  a  small  enterprise 
should have revenue of CNY3 million–CNY20 million and 20–300 employees; a micro enterprise should have less 
than CNY3 million revenue or less than 20 employees. 
2  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
3   Real gross domestic product growth for 2011 was 9.2% and inflation was 4.1%. Foreign direct investment reached 

an all time high of $115.86 billion in 2011. 

4   Sector Overview (accessible from linked documents in Appendix 2). 
5   An  inclusive  financial  system is  one  that services  all  clients,  not  just  the  relatively  well  off.  This  means servicing 

poor and low-income clients with a wide range of accessible products. 

6  This is due to unreliable financial reporting, lack of collateral and guarantees, lack of credit rating and general credit 

information, and loan officers responsibility for loan losses. 

7   ADB. 2004. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Rural Finance Reforms and Development 
of  Microfinance  Institutions.  Manila  (TA  4430–PRC,  $1  million).  The  technical  assistance  established  MCCs  as 
pilots  in  the  Inner  Mongolia  Autonomous  Region  and  in  Guizhou  Province;  MCCs  were  subsequently  replicated 
nationwide. 

8   According  to  PBC  statistics  on  MCCs,  at  the  end  of  August  2011  the  whole  sector  had  3,687  MCCs,  39,353 
employees,  CNY273  billion  total  capital,  and  CNY319  billion  total  loans  outstanding.  The  Inner  Mongolia 
Autonomous Region had the most MCCs—its top eight provinces accounted for more than 50% of all MCCs. 

 2 

 

and funding sources—as well as natural funding restrictions due to their status as non-deposit-
taking institutions. MCCs generally focus on areas they are familiar with and, despite restrictions 
and unfavorable tax treatment, their average profitability after tax is a 9% return on equity. The 
development of MCCs has brought healthy competition to the microfinance market. In addition 
to  MCCs,  there  are  also  active  institutions  such  as  rural  credit  cooperatives,  rural  commercial 
banks,  postal  saving  banks,  village  and  township  banks  (VTBs),  lending  subsidiaries  of 
commercial  banks,  and  farmer  credit  unions.  Among  these,  VTBs  are  most  comparable  to 
MCCs;  however,  unlike  MCCs  they  take  deposits.  The  development  of  VTBs  has  been  much 
slower than that of MCCs—there were 440 VTBs as of June 2011. 

5. 
The  China  Banking  Regulatory  Commission  (CBRC)  is  responsible  for  supervising 
deposit-taking  institutions,  but  not  MCCs.  The  key  document  providing  the  basis  for  the 
regulatory framework for MCCs is the Guide Regarding MCC Pilots,  issued jointly by the PBC 
and CBRC in 2008,9 which serves as the basis for local regulations issued by provincial finance 
offices.10
 Local finance offices actively exchange experiences and ideas, and better practices in 
one  province  can  be  quickly  adopted  in  others.  MCC  associations  at  provincial  and  national 
levels also act as self-regulatory bodies. 

B. 

Rationale 

Despite rapid growth MCCs face several challenges, the most critical being the shortage 
6. 
of  funding  sources  to  reach  economies  of  scale  for  commercial  sustainability.  When  ADB  and 
the PBC worked on MCC pilots in 2004–2005, a decision was made to allow  MCCs to borrow 
from no more than two wholesale lenders amounts up to 50% of their equity capital. By August 
2011,  loan  funds  accounted  for  only  about  10%  of  overall  MCC  funding  sources.  There  has 
been  some  lending  to  MCCs  from  large  state-owned  banks  such  as  the  China  Development 
Bank,  the  Bank  of  Communications,  and  the  Shanghai  Pudong  Development  Bank.  However, 
none  of  these  larger  banks  were  able  to sustain  loans  to  MCCs  due  to  limitations  in  the  bank 
branch networks and lack of efficient decision-making processes at the local level. 

7. 
MCCs urgently need access to wholesale lending from banks. Most MCCs deploy their 
funds in 2–3 months and recycle funds from repaid loans, as most loans are of short duration. 
The  development  of  the  microfinance  wholesale  market  has  been  slow,  but  there  is  scope  to 
expand.  Local  commercial  banks  are  potentially  strong  wholesalers  for  MCCs,  as  they  are 
licensed  for  the  local  market  and  have  better  understanding  of  and  access  to  MCCs.  A  well-
developed wholesale market can (i) strengthen the financial and operational capacity of MCCs 
to  better  serve  rural  and micro  borrowers, (ii)  provide  a  channel for  local  commercial  banks to 
improve  their  presence  in  the  microfinance  market  through  MCCs,  and  (iii)  establish  a  market 
mechanism to increase transparency in the MCC sector for improved regulatory oversight. 

8. 
ADB will  work with local partner banks, as ADB’s direct borrowers, to channel funds to 
MCCs  and  the  microfinance  market.  The  facility  is  expected  to  have  a  significant  catalytic 
impact  through  a  learning-by-doing  process,  helping  local  partner  banks  establish  MCC 

                                                
9   Government  of the  PRC,  CBRC,  and  PBC.  2008.  Guide  Regarding  MCC  Pilots.  Beijing,  (in  Chinese.)  The  guide 
specifies  that  MCCs  are  limited  liability  companies  sponsored  by  corporations  or  natural  persons,  engaging  in 
microlending. The guide prescribed the following: (i) general requirements for MCC establishment and dissolution; 
(ii)  source,  size,  and  use  of  capital;  (iii)  product  and  geographical  restrictions;  (iv)  risk  management  parameters, 
such  as single  borrower  limit;  and  (v)  general  regulatory  norms such as  accounting  and  reporting, interest  rates, 
general and special provisions, and access to the credit information bureau. 

10 The  local  government  finance  office  is  in  charge  of  development  of  local  financial  markets.  The  China  Finance 
Office Joint Conference Center (http://www.govfn.com) serves as the coordinating mechanism for local government 
finance offices nationwide. 

 

   3 

wholesale  lending  as  a  regular  line  of  business.  More  local  banks  will  be  encouraged  to 
participate in wholesale lending to MCCs once they see this as a profitable business with both 
financial and social impacts. A pre-established set of criteria will be applied in selecting partner 
banks. The banks will undergo a thorough due diligence process and review to ensure prudent 
credit and financial standing. Potential partner banks do not yet have experience in microfinance 
wholesale  lending.  However,  they  have  participated  in  the  World  Bank’s  technical  assistance 
(TA)  for  developing  micro  and  small  and  medium-sized  enterprise  financing  operations  and 
have  competent  micro  and  small  and  medium-sized  enterprise  financing  teams.  With  these 
skills and further training, they can enter the MCC wholesale market segment reasonably easily. 

ADB  will  contribute  to  capacity  development  of  partner  banks  through  ADB’s  TA  for 
9. 
Capacity  Development  of  Partner  Banks  in  Microfinance Wholesale  Lending11
  that  will  provide 
training in establishing commercially sustainable MCC wholesale lending programs. Training will 
cover  business  strategies,  market  development  plans,  loan  underwriting  and  borrower 
evaluation  techniques,  risk  management,  loan  portfolio  management,  collection,  loan  workout 
methodologies,  and  delinquent  loan  resolution.  Safeguards  will  also  be  addressed  here  to 
ensure  participating  bank  systems  meet  ADB  requirements.  Training  materials  will  be 
disseminated to other local banks to encourage further wholesale lending to MCCs. 

C. 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 

10. 
One  of  the  key  strategic  directions  of  the  country  partnership  strategy  (2008–2010)  for 
the PRC was inclusive growth and balanced development, focusing operations on poorer inland 
provinces  and  promoting  integrated  rural  and  urban  development.12  The  country  partnership 
strategy (2011–2015) currently in preparation continues to recognize inclusive growth as one of 
the three pillars to foster balanced and equitable development. Strengthening access to finance 
through the microfinance sector will have a strong impact on poverty alleviation. Finance sector 
development  is  listed  as  one  of  the  five  core  areas  of  ADB’s  development  agenda  under 
Strategy  2020.13  The  Financial  Sector  Operational  Plan  identifies  financial  inclusion  as  one  of 
the  two  pillars. 14  ADB’s  Finance  for  the  Poor:  Microfinance  Development  Strategy15
  calls  for 
tapping the increasing potential of the poor by expanding access to microfinance. By increasing 
resources to MCCs and their borrowers, there will be greater participation of the private sector 
income. 
in  economic  growth,  creating  more  employment  opportunities  and 
Additionally,  access  to  microcredit  and  other  financial  services  helps  the  poor  to  improve 
incomes and withstand economic shocks. 

increased 

ADB  has  continuously  supported  the  rural  and  microfinance  sectors  in  the  PRC.  In 
11. 
addition  to  its  groundbreaking  work  in  2004  to  develop  privately  owned  commercially 
sustainable  MFIs,  ADB  is  now  partnering  with  (i)  the  PBC  to  support  innovations  in  rural  and 
microfinance and improve rural finance statistics, (ii) the CBRC to strengthen the rural finance 
regulatory framework, and (iii) credit rating companies to develop credit and social performance 
ratings  for  MCCs.
  This  facility  shares  synergies  with  the  microfinance  risk  participation 

16

                                                
11 ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance for the People’s Republic of China for Capacity Development of Partner Banks in 
Microfinance Wholesale Lending. Manila (TA 7765–PRC, $225,000, accessible from the list of linked documents in 
Appendix 2). 

12 ADB. 2008. Country Partnership Strategy: People’s Republic of China, 2008–2010. Manila.

Manila. 

14 ADB. 2011. Financial Sector Operational Plan. Manila. 
15 ADB. 2000. Finance for the Poor: Microfinance Development Strategy. Manila. 
16 ADB.  2008.  Technical  Assistance  to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  Rural  Finance  Development  and 
Supervision. Manila (TA 7187–PRC, $400,000); and ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of 

 4 

 

program developed by ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department.17
 The partner banks which 
have  participated  in  the facility  and  developed  a  wholesale  MCC  lending business  will  be  in  a 
good position to participate in the risk participation program to scale up operations. 

D. 

Development Impact 

12. 
Impact.  The impact of the facility will be improved access to finance for entrepreneurs, 
MSEs, and poor households in the central and western regions of the PRC, thus contributing to 
economic and private sector growth and poverty reduction. 

Outcome. The outcome will be successful establishment of the MCC wholesale lending 

13. 
market. With ADB’s participation, partner banks will be developing a new niche product. 

Outputs.  The  facility  outputs  will  include  the  following:  (i)  development  of  selective 
14. 
partner  banks’  wholesale  lending  capacity  to  MCCs,  including  establishing  prudent  business 
processes  and  safeguards  to  ensure  both  financial  and  social  performance  of  MCCs;  (ii) 
strengthened financial and institutional capabilities of MCCs, including enhanced gender equity 
aspects;  and  (iii)  effective  regulatory  oversight  for  the  MCC  market  through  strengthened 
relationships among MCCs, local banks, and local government regulators. 

15. 
Gender. Globally, microfinance has been an effective tool for addressing some issues of 
gender inequality. Of the 1.3 billion people living in poverty, 70% are women. Women make up 
40%–70% of the informal sector, and they often enter the labor force through micro enterprises, 
yet they are usually excluded from access to finance.18 In the PRC, microfinance has shown a 
positive impact on women, providing increased participation in decision making, improved status 
in  the  household  and  in  communities,  and  enhanced  skills  in  and  knowledge  of  financial 
services.19
 Women  also  play  an  important role  in  MCC  development.  For example,  in  Jiangsu 
Province more than half of the MCCs are owned by women, and in most MCCs more than half 
of the staff and clients are women. 

16. 
The facility will further promote women’s participation in MCCs. Female targets of 30% 
of  staff  to  be  trained  in  the  partner  banks  and  30%  of  MCC  clients  as  borrowers  under  the 
facility  will  encourage  stronger  engagement.  Depending  on  market  demand,  there  will  also  be 
financial literacy training, supported by partner banks, targeting up to 50% women. 

III. 

THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 

A. 

The Assistance 

The ADB assistance in aggregate not exceeding CNY130 million will be made available 
17. 
to  selected  partner  banks 20
  for  onlending  to  MCCs  in  the  PRC.  The  facility  will  provide 
nonsovereign  unsecured  loans  to  selected  partner  banks  of  not  more  than  CNY40  million  per 
bank.  The  facility  will  have  a  4-year  availability  period,  subject  to  ADB’s  satisfaction  with  the 
facility’s  performance,  two  years  after the first  credit  agreement  is signed  with  a  partner  bank. 

                                                                                                                                                       
China  for  Rural  Finance  Innovation  and  Rural  and  Agriculture  Financial  Statistical  System  Development.  Manila 
(TA 7322–PRC, $500,000). 

17  ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance for Microfinance Risk Participation Program. Manila (TA 73525-REG). 
18  Dena M. Burjorjee et al. 2002. UN Capital Development Fund, Supporting Women’s Livelihoods: Microfinance that 

Works for the Majority. New York. 

19  G. He, X. Du, C. Bai, and Z. Li. 2009. China Microfinance Industry Assessment Report.  Beijing. 
20  Potential Partner Banks (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

 

   5 

Loans  may  have  a  maximum  tenor  of  3  years,  so  the  facility  will  have  a  maximum  tenor  of  7 
years. Principal repaid within the availability period may be reborrowed.21
 

18. 
Loans made to partner banks through this facility will have tenors of up to 3 years with 
amortization starting 1 year after the first disbursement. Loan amounts made available to each 
partner  bank  will  be  determined  based  on  repayment  ability  and  capacity  to  develop  an  MCC 
wholesale  lending  business.  Loan  interest  will  be  based  on  the  3-month  Shanghai  interbank 
offered rate or other appropriate benchmark plus an appropriate spread. 

19.  MCCs will be initially screened by partner banks and assessed against  ADB's eligibility 
criteria  for  the  facility.  Partner  banks  will  conduct  due  diligence  in  accordance  with  ADB's 
requirements and in line with ADB policies on anticorruption, safeguards, gender, integrity, and 
procurement. ADB will conduct due diligence on potential partner banks and submit reports to 
the Investment Committee for approval. Appropriate facility limits and other sublimits for partner 
banks and MCCs will be maintained, unless otherwise approved by the Investment Committee. 

Partner bank eligibility for ADB financing and selection process. The facility will be 
20. 
open to banks that meet the eligibility criteria and are approved by the Investment Committee. A 
final  set  of eligibility  criteria  will  be  determined  based  on  the results  of  due  diligence  and  term 
negotiations with potential partner banks. Eligibility criteria will include the following: 

(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

(iv) 

(v) 
(vi) 

(vii) 

(viii) 

(ix) 

using the proceeds solely for wholesale lending to MCCs, and providing funding 
equal to ADB’s contribution wholesale lending; 
having  a  sound  ownership  and  management  structure  and  a  business  plan  for 
the microfinance sector, and working with recognized auditors; 
having worked, or working satisfactorily, to develop credit standards and internal 
risk  rating  systems  that  pass  detailed  ADB  due  diligence  and  the  Investment 
Committee process; 
having a dedicated team handling MCC relationships and risk management, and 
have  in  place,  or  be  developing,  an  acceptable  underwriting  and  servicing 
platform; 
ensuring that lending does not cause adverse environmental or social impacts; 
exhibiting financial soundness22
 as evidenced by adequate capital, asset quality, 
liquidity, and profitability, including (a) maintaining the capital adequacy ratio and 
other regulatory requirements prescribed by the banking regulator, (b) a ratio of 
nonperforming  assets  of  less  than  5%,  (c)  a  current ratio  higher  than  20%,  and 
(d) no default history on own obligations; 
having  a  credit  rating  of  BB–  and  above  or  equivalent,  or  an  NSO8  (employing 
ADB's internal ratings system); 
committing  to  establish  an  environmental  and  social  management  system 
(ESMS) to ensure due diligence and mitigation of adequate impacts in all stages 
of  facility  operation  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement 
(2009),  and  adopting  the  agreed  selection  criteria  set  out  in  the  environmental 
and social assessment and review framework and committed to engage qualified 
staff or train staff to implement ESMS; and 
not having previously borrowed from the facility. 

                                                
21  Implementation  Arrangements—Chart  of  Project  Flow  of  Funds  (accessible  from  the  list  of  linked  documents  in 

Appendix 2). 

22 At the minimum, all partner banks will need to meet all regulatory ratio requirements set by the CBRC for capital 

adequacy, nonperforming loans liquidity,  overall bank liquidity, and operations. 

 6 

 

Additional criteria may be included in the loan documents for any or all partner banks. To 
21. 
participate in the facility, partner banks must participate in the small-scale capacity development 
TA. In allocating funds from the facility, ADB will review up to five partner banks, and no single 
bank will receive more than CNY40 million. Risk will be spread across multiple partner banks. 

22. 

Partner banks will be selected according to the following assessment process: 
(i) 

Identify  candidate  partner  banks.  ADB  will  identify  candidate  partner  banks 
through market research, referrals from respected microfinance equity investors, 
and referrals from ADB’s peer institutions. To merit consideration, partner banks 
must meet the selection criteria described in para. 20. 
Due diligence. ADB will conduct due diligence on each of the candidate partner 
banks  under  consideration.  Due  diligence  will  be  a  standard  assessment  of  the 
candidate as a financial institution, with a focus on (a) the overall strength of the 
institution; (b) its capacity to deploy an ADB loan for wholesale lending to MCCs, 
and continue to engage in the wholesale market thereafter; and (c) its capacity to 
repay the loan to ADB. 
Project  proposal. Based on the due diligence results, ADB will decide whether 
to  proceed  with  processing  a  loan  to  any  candidate  partner  bank  and  will 
determine the terms of the proposed loan. This determination will be in keeping 
with market funding costs and will explore loan structures as appropriate. 

(ii) 

(iii) 

Subject to approval and agreement on the terms, ADB will sign documentation with the 

23. 
partner bank and the loan will be disbursed through ADB’s standard systems. 

24.  Microcredit  companies’  eligibility  to  use  funds.  Funds  borrowed  by  partner  banks 
from  the  facility  can  only  be  used  for  wholesale  lending  to  eligible  MCCs.  Eligibility  criteria  for 
MCCs include the following: 

(i) 
(ii) 
(iii) 
(iv) 
(v) 
(vi) 

being legally registered as MCCs with at least 2 years history of operations; 
focusing on lending to MSEs and households; 
exhibiting financial soundness and loan repayment ability; 
working with recognized auditors; 
having clear shareholding structures; 
having  worked,  or  working  satisfactorily,  to  develop  risk  management  systems 
and other operational structures acceptable to both ADB and partner banks; 
ensuring  that  lending  does  not  cause  any  adverse  environmental  or  social 
impacts, and paying particular attention to women clients; 
having a clean credit and background history (for both MCC and its sponsors); 

(viii) 
(ix)  may have an acceptable external credit and social performance rating;23
(x)

and  reporting  arrangement  to  partner  banks,  and  (b)  engage  qualified  staff  or 
train staff to properly implement the ESMS. 

 and

25.  Microcredit  companies’  lending  parameters.  Subject to negotiations with the partner 
banks, MCCs that borrow facility funds from partner banks may be required to make loans with 
those funds, after satisfying the following criteria: 

(i) 

all proceeds of the facility borrowed from partner banks must be onlent to micro 
entrepreneurs and MSEs as defined by the government in June 2011;24

with the company and international partners to implement credit and social performance rating systems for MCCs.

(ii) 

(iii) 
(iv) 
(v) 

(vi) 

(vii) 
(viii) 

the  average  loan  size  in  each  MCC  portfolio  funded  by  the  facility  is  not  to 
exceed  CNY200,000  and  the maximum  is  not to  exceed  CNY1 million  or  single 
borrower limited, whichever is lower;25
 
no loan will finance activities listed in ADB's prohibited investment activity list; 
loans must comply with applicable national and local laws and regulations; 
to  facilitate  financial  inclusiveness  for  women,  MCCs  will  ensure  women 
borrowers sign or co-sign at least 30% of loans; 
loan maturity dates to final borrowers must not occur later than the maturity date 
of loans from the partner banks; 
at least 50% of the loans to MSEs should have tenors of less than 1 year; and 
borrowers  must  be  selected  using  subborrower  selection  and  exclusion  criteria 
set out in the ESMS established by partner banks for MCCs. 

26. 
Confirmation  of  eligibility  of  microcredit  companies.  Partner  banks  will  be 
responsible  for  selecting  MCCs  according  to  the  agreed  upon  eligibility  criteria  and  for 
submitting reports to ADB for no-objection. 

Submission  of  candidate  MCCs  by  the  partner  bank. The partner banks will 
submit  a  list  of  MCCs  to  ADB  for  no-objection,  using  a  pre-agreed  format, 
together with the financial, operational, and market information required to enable 
ADB to conduct reviews. 26
 
Evaluation  and  confirmation.  ADB  will  conduct  a  review  of  MCCs  against  the 
established  eligibility  criteria.  The  no-objection  will  be  summarized  in  a  pre-
agreed format to be communicated to the partner banks. 

Reporting  requirements.  Efficient  and  effective  reporting  arrangements  from  partner 
27. 
banks to ADB and from MCCs to partner banks are essential to ensure successful operation of 
the facility. These will include the following: 

from  partner  banks  to  ADB:  annual  reports  in  English  for  evaluation  of  MCCs, 
annual reports of MCC wholesale lending portfolio performance, implementation 
status  of  ESMS  both  at  MCC  level  and  at  the  partner  bank  level,  and  audited 
annual financial statements; and 
from  MCCs  to  partner  banks:  semiannual  summary  table  of  subloans,  selected 
subloan  files  and  completed  ESMS  checklists  and  status  for  subloans,  portfolio 
performance information,  and annual financial statements. 

(i) 

(ii) 

(i) 

(ii) 

B. 

Investment Cost and Financing Plan 

28. 
The financing plan for each partner bank will depend on the results of the detailed due 
diligence of that bank and final negotiation. In terms of market demand, using the five provinces 
that  the  ADB  project  team  visited  as  an  example,  there  are  more  than  850  MCCs  with  total 
registered  capital  estimated  at  CNY45.4  billion.  These  equity  levels  would  give  them  room  to 
borrow up to CNY22.7 billion. Assuming that about 25% of these MCCs are eligible to borrow, 
with  partner  banks  contributing  50%  and  the  facility  only  providing  5%  of  borrowing  needs, 
ADB’s  total  contribution  will  be  CNY130  million  and  partner  banks  will  contribute  another 
CNY130 million for a total of CNY260 million lent to MCCs. 

                                                
25  A  loan  is  generally  considered  as  micro  credit  if  it  is  less  than  CNY50,000;  the  CBRC  allows  it  to  be  less  than 

CNY300,000. The single borrower limit is set at 5% of net capital by most local governments. 

26  ADB will conduct a detailed review of the first batch of MCCs submitted by each partner bank to ensure that each 

bank has adequate capability in selecting and evaluation of MCCs. 

 8

C. 

Justification for ADB Assistance 

29.  MCCs are constrained in their ability to meet the demand for financial services to MSEs 
and the poor due to lack of capital. Commercial banks have been reluctant to lend to MCCs due 
to their unfamiliarity with the microfinance market and lack of technical skills to evaluate loans to 
MCCs.  ADB  intervention  and  capacity  building  support  in  working  with  commercial  banks  for 
wholesale lending to MCCs will encourage banks to engage with MCCs, familiarize themselves 
with  the market,  and  develop  efficient  systems and  procedures.  Additionally,  since  the  partner 
banks  will  take  the  MCC  credit  risk,  they  will  have  strong  incentives  to  develop  prudent  and 
effective  risk  underwriting  and  an  appropriate  risk  management  framework.  Availability  of 
wholesale  funding  will  enhance  sustainability  of  MCCs  and  result  in  reduced  cost  for  micro 
borrowers.  The  facility  will  be  fully  dedicated  to  supporting  and  developing  the  MCC  sector  in 
the  PRC.  The  targeted  nature  of  this  intervention  will  have  significant  development  impact  in 
poor and underserved regions. 

D. 

Risk and Mitigation Measures 

Risks  embedded  in  the  transaction  will  include  various  credit,  market,  regulatory,  and 

30. 
operational risks of partner banks: 

(i)  Bank  performance  risk.  The  ability  of  partner  banks  to  maintain  acceptable 
financial  performance  levels  may  be  affected  by  changes  in  risk  appetite, 
maintenance  of  credit  underwriting  and  monitoring  procedures,  asset  quality, 
liquidity  conditions  and  regulatory  environment,  all  of  which  must  be  carefully 
assessed.  The  main  sources  of  systemic  risk  are:  the  impact  of  rapid  credit 
expansion  on  credit  quality,  growing  off-balance  sheet  exposures,  reversals  of 
rapidly rising real estate prices, and unbalanced economic growth patterns27. ADB 
will  review  the  financial  strength  of  each  partner  bank  and  a  minimum  rating 
threshold based on ADB’s internal rating assessment of LCY ORR of NSO 8 (BB-) 
or better will be required for participation in the program.28
  

(ii)  Regulatory  risk.  The  changing  regulatory  landscape  poses  a  risk  to  effective 
utilization of the facility especially because microfinance in the PRC is in a nascent 
phase  and  the  sector  lacks  customized  policies  and  laws.  The  MCC  sector  is 
supervised  by  local  government  entities  and  provincial  financial  market  offices 
which  may  have  varying  experience  with  these  entities,  therefore  each  partner 
bank  application  must  include  an  assessment  of  the  local  regulatory  framework. 
Additionally,  regulators  in  PRC  exert  influence  over  credit  policies  of  the  banks 
which  could  impact  the  MWLF  program.  This  may  be  partially  addressed  by 
continuing the close work with the CBRC on methods of increasing access to funds 
in  rural  areas,  and  requesting  banks  to  seek  written  approval  from  regulators 
before proceeding to develop MCC wholesale financing.   

                                                
27 PRC: Financial System Stability Report, International Monetary Fund (2011). 
28

Additional  credit  enhancements  such  as  guarantees  of  repayment  obligations  of  partner  banks  by  third-party 
guarantee companies will be considered by ADB, as appropriate. 

 

   9 

(iii)  Limited  capacity  for  MCC  lending.  Commercial  banks  have  no  experience  in 
MCC  wholesale  lending  and  consequently,  have  no  established  underwriting  and 
risk management processes tailored to this segment. This shortcoming is expected 
to  be  addressed  through  participation  in  ADB’s  technical  assistance,  which  is  a 
requirement for each partner bank. 

(iv)  Replacement  risk.  ADB’s  program  in  terms  of  size  is  limited  compared  to  the 
overall needs of the market. However, the impact is expected to extend beyond the 
program in mainstreaming the MCC wholesale lending market. The risk is that the 
partner  banks  will  not  maintain  the  wholesale  lending  business  with  their  own 
capital and will terminate the program upon repayment of the ADB loan. Mitigation 
involves close work with the banks to ensure commercial success for wholesaling 
to MCCs. 

(v)  MCC  and  microlending  risks.  As  a  new  type  of  microfinance  institution  which 
previously  has  not  enjoyed  stable funding  sources, there  is  limited  information  on 
MCC  performance  and  repayment  history.  MCCs  extend 
to  micro 
entrepreneurs and MSEs, most of whom have low income, few pledgeable assets, 
and little or no credit history. Operational costs are higher due to the large volume 
of  transactions  in  smaller  amounts.  MCCs  are  located  in  communities  and 
potentially have better knowledge of their borrowers than larger banks, and report 
low rates of loan impairment so far.29
 

loans 

(vi)  Audit  and  reporting  standards.  Loan  review  missions  will  closely  monitor  the 
quality of audit and reporting of partner banks and the MCCs, which in some cases 
may  be  less  than  is  needed  to  reveal  true  financial  and  operational  information. 
International  auditing  standards  are  not  consistently  practiced  by  city  commercial 
banks in the PRC. Partner banks must work with recognized auditors and commit 
to  disclosures  and  reporting.  Partner  banks  are  also  required  to  submit  annual 
financial statements in English. 

A. 

Safeguards and Social Dimensions 

IV. 

POLICY COMPLIANCE 

The  facility  is  classified  FI,  treated  as  C  for  environment,  involuntary  resettlement,  and 
31. 
indigenous  peoples  under  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement.30  The  facility  will  only  support 
MSE lending with minimal or no adverse environmental impacts, and which is  unlikely to have 
impacts on involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples. The partner banks and MCCs will 
(i) apply ADB’s prohibited investment activities list, (ii) exclude all projects that will have adverse 
environmental  and  social  safeguards  impacts,  (iii)  ensure  that  investments  using  ADB  funds 
abide by applicable national laws and regulations, and (iv) comply with ADB’s Safeguard Policy 
Statement.  The  ESMS  will  comprise  screening  procedures  and  reporting  arrangements  to 
partner banks and arrangements to comply with national labor laws and ADB’s Social Protection 
Strategy31
  to  ensure  adherence  to  internationally  recognized  core  labor  standards,  including 
provisions  prohibiting  any  discrimination  against  women  in  hiring  and  providing  equal  pay  for 
equal work for men and women. Partner banks will review ESMS developed by MCCs , monitor 
the  performance  of  these  ESMSs,  and  submit  consolidated  reports  to  ADB  annually  and  on 
project completion. MCCs will screen MSE applicants using a screening checklist, and report to 
the  partner  bank  on  ESMS  performance  on  an  annual  basis.  ADB  has  prepared  the 
environmental  and  social  assessment  and  review  framework  to  ensure  that  relevant  PRC  and 

                                                
29 Currently, MCC loan loss ratios are very low (less than 1% in those reviewed in the field). 
30 Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from linked documents in Appendix 2). 
31 ADB. 2001. Social Protection Strategy. Manila. 

 10 

 

Safeguard  Policy  Statement  environmental  and  social  safeguards  are  included  in  the  MCC 
selection  and/or  exclusion  criteria  of  the  recipients  of  microfinance  lending. 32
  Based  on  this 
framework,  each  partner  bank  as  well  as  each  MCC  will  develop  and  establish  an  ESMS  to 
ensure  due  diligence  and  adequate  impact  mitigation  in  all  stages  of  facility  operation  in 
accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement before the first disbursement of funds. The 
ESMSs prepared by partner banks will be documented and agreed upon with ADB prior to loan 
effectiveness. 

B. 

Anticorruption Policy 

32. 
 Partner  banks  will  be  advised  of  ADB’s  policy  of  implementing  best  international 
practice relating to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB 
will  ensure  that  the  investment  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions  prohibiting 
corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism, and remedies for ADB in the event 
of noncompliance. 

The proposed loan lies within the country, industry, group, and medium-term and single 

33. 
project exposure limits for nonsovereign investments. 

C. 

Investment Limitations 

D. 

Assurances 

No objection. Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank 
34. 
(the Charter),33
 the Government of the People’s Republic of China will be requested to confirm 
that  it  has  no  objection  to  the  proposed  financing.  ADB  will  enter  into  suitable  finance 
documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed 
assistance  by  its  Board  of  Directors  and  selection  and  approval  of  partner  banks  by  the 
Investment Committee. 

35. 
Documentation. ADB will enter into suitable loan agreements and other required legal 
documents  with  partner  banks  once  the  individual  loan  terms  are  approved  by  ADB’s 
Investment Committee. The agreements will be on terms and conditions satisfactory to ADB.

34
 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

36. 
 I am satisfied that the proposed facility would comply with the Articles of Agreement of 
the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
CNY130,000,000  for  the  Microfinance  Wholesale  Lending  Facility  in  the  People’s  Republic  of 
China  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources,  with  such  terms  and  conditions  as  are 
substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  this  report,  and  as  may  be  reported  to  the 
Board. 

 

6 March 2012 

Haruhiko Kuroda 
President

Activities with Milestones 
1.  Selective partner banks’ wholesale lending capacity to MCCs  
1.1  Due diligence undertaken on partner banks, including review of 

microfinance portfolio, business plan, credit underwriting, and monitoring 
processes. 

1.2  Guidelines and standard operating procedures prepared. 
1.3  Small-scale capacity development technical assistance implemented to 

assist partner banks in developing and upgrading their business processes 
and strengthen weaknesses in preparation for loan disbursement. 
1.4  Appropriate documentation with banks and loans disbursed to partner 

1.5  Partner banks monitor and manage underlying risk exposure on an 

banks. 

ongoing basis. 

1.6  Staff in partner banks trained in loan underwriting and enterprise evaluation 
techniques, risk management, loan portfolio management, collection 
practice, and loan workout methodologies, as well as delinquent loan 
resolution. 

1.7   While selecting partner banks, an agreement on the environmental and 

social assessment and review frameworka

 is reached. 

1.8   Partner banks and MCCs develop respective environmental and social 

management system. 

2.  Financial and institutional capabilities of the MCCs  
2.1  Eligibility criteria established for MCCs to participate in the facility. 
2.2  MCC business strategies and market development plans developed. 
2.3  Gaps in efficiency minimized and quality of services improved. 
2.4  Guidelines and standard operating procedures for MCCs prepared. 
2.5   MCCs monitor and manage underlying risk exposure on an ongoing basis. 
2.6  Financial literacy training conducted with at least 50% female participants. 
3.  Regulatory oversight for MCC market  
3.1  Partner banks assist in improving MCCs’ risk management capabilities. 
3.2   Partner banks report MCC portfolio performance to local government, 

financial regulators, and ADB at agreed intervals 

3.3   Local finance offices consult regularly with partner banks and MCCs to 

learn and improve related regulatory structures. 

3.4  Knowledge dissemination and training for microfinance market 

stakeholders is undertaken. 

ADB = Asian Development Bank, MCC = microcredit company, MSE = micro and small enterprise, PBC = People’s
